title: Cost Estimation & Budgeting
description: Learn to select appropriate cost estimation techniques and structure budgets with proper reserve allocation.
objectives: Select appropriate estimation technique (bottom-up, analogous, parametric, three-point) based on data availability and detail level needed
Understand budget component hierarchy: Cost Baseline → Contingency Reserve → Management Reserve → Project Budget → Total Funding
Distinguish between contingency reserves (known risks from risk register) and management reserves (unknown unknowns, unforeseen events)
Apply cost aggregation from work packages to control accounts to project budget
Recognize WBS as the foundation for cost estimation in predictive projects

screens.headline: $2.8M expansion budget. One question: Can you justify every dollar?

visual.left: Alex's budget breakdown showing three-layer pyramid: $2.5M baseline, $200K contingency, $100K management reserve
visual.right: Elena (CFO) reviewing financial statements with skeptical expression, red circles highlighting reserve amounts

dialogue.text: I see $2.5M in estimates, then you add $200K contingency and $100K management reserve. Why the extra $300K? Is this just padding? Convince me these numbers are real.

screens.learningHook: Three work packages need estimates. Three techniques to choose from. Wrong choice = budget rejected by CFO.

screens.title: Choose Estimation Techniques & Structure the Budget
screens.instructions: Stage 1: Select the appropriate estimation technique for each work package. Stage 2: Arrange budget components in the correct hierarchy.

workPackages.title: Location Build-Out

context.historicalData: Yes (completed 2 similar expansions in past 18 months)

workPackages.question: Which technique should Alex use to estimate the $1.8M construction cost?

options.text: Analogous (Top-Down) - Use past project costs as basis, adjust for differences
Parametric - Use cost per square foot ($350/sq ft) × total square footage (6,000 sq ft)
Bottom-Up - Estimate each WBS work package individually, then sum
Three-Point Estimating - For each WBS element, estimate optimistic, most likely, pessimistic

feedback.correct: Perfect! HIGH detail needed (investor presentation) + Clear scope + Historical data available = BOTTOM-UP. Elena needs itemized breakdown to defend to board.
feedback.incorrect: Review: High detail + clear scope = Bottom-Up. Elena needs itemized costs for investor presentation, not just a ballpark estimate.

workPackages.title: Technology Infrastructure

context.scopeClarity: Medium (requirements defined, but vendor implementation varies)
context.historicalData: No (switching to new POS vendor, unfamiliar system)

workPackages.question: Which technique should Alex use to estimate the $400K technology cost?

options.text: Analogous (Top-Down) - Use industry benchmarks for restaurant tech stacks
Parametric - Use cost per location × 3 locations
Bottom-Up - Get detailed quotes for POS, inventory system, WiFi, security
Three-Point Estimating - Estimate optimistic, most likely, pessimistic; use weighted average

feedback.correct: Excellent! HIGH UNCERTAINTY (new vendor, unfamiliar system) + No historical data = THREE-POINT. Alex gets range: Optimistic $320K, Most Likely $400K, Pessimistic $550K.
feedback.incorrect: High uncertainty with new vendor requires Three-Point estimating to capture the range of possible outcomes.

workPackages.title: Marketing Launch Campaign

context.scopeClarity: Medium (strategy approved, but creative execution TBD)
context.historicalData: Yes (launched 2 locations previously, have vendor rates)
context.uncertainty: Medium (creative agencies quote ranges, not fixed prices)

workPackages.question: Which technique should Alex use to estimate the $300K marketing cost?

options.text: Analogous (Top-Down) - Use past launch costs adjusted for 3 locations and inflation
Parametric - Use cost per location × 3 locations
Bottom-Up - Itemize each deliverable (billboards, social ads, PR events)
Three-Point Estimating - Get optimistic, most likely, pessimistic quotes from agencies

feedback.correct: Perfect! HISTORICAL DATA exists (past 2-location launch = $180K) + QUICK ESTIMATE needed = ANALOGOUS. Alex adjusts for 3 locations + inflation → $300K.
feedback.incorrect: With historical data from similar past launches, Analogous estimating is the most efficient approach.

stages.title: Structure the Budget Components
stages.description: Alex has $2.5M in estimates. Elena asks: 'Now add contingency and management reserves. Show me the budget hierarchy.'
stages.question: Drag and drop the 5 budget components in correct order from bottom (foundation) to top (total funding):

components.label: Cost Baseline
components.description: Sum of all work package estimates

components.label: Contingency Reserve
components.description: For identified risks (supply chain delays, permit issues)

feedback.perfect: Perfect hierarchy! You nailed the PMBOK structure: Cost Baseline → + Contingency = Project Budget → + Management = Total Funding.
feedback.partial: Close! Review: Cost Baseline is the foundation. Contingency (known risks) comes before Management reserve (unknowns).
feedback.incorrect: Review the budget hierarchy. Start with Cost Baseline (estimates), add Contingency (known risks), then Management reserve (unknowns).

decisionFactors: Detail Level Needed: High detail → Bottom-Up or Parametric. Low detail → Analogous or Three-Point.
Data Availability: Historical data available → Analogous. Cost-per-unit parameter → Parametric. No reliable data → Three-Point.
Uncertainty Level: High uncertainty → Three-Point. Low uncertainty with clear scope → Bottom-Up.

techniques.name: Bottom-Up
techniques.whenToUse: High-detail needs, clear scope, itemized breakdown required

techniques.name: Analogous (Top-Down)
techniques.whenToUse: Early planning, quick estimate, similar past projects exist

layers.name: Cost Baseline
layers.definition: Sum of all approved WBS work package cost estimates

layers.name: Contingency Reserve
layers.definition: Budget for KNOWN risks identified during risk planning
layers.whoControls: Project Manager (can use with documented risk trigger)
layers.example: Supply chain delays, permit issues - Expected value = $200K

layers.name: Project Budget
layers.whoControls: Project Manager (full authority within this budget)

layers.name: Total Project Funding
layers.example: What Elena must present to the board

insights.title: WBS is the foundation for cost estimation
insights.explanation: You can't estimate costs without knowing WHAT you're building. Bottom-up estimation relies on WBS structure.

insights.title: Contingency vs Management reserves are different
insights.explanation: Contingency = known risks (PM controls). Management = unknowns (sponsor controls). Don't confuse them.

insights.title: Reserves are NOT padding
insights.explanation: Reserves are justified by risk analysis. Cutting them doesn't make risks disappear—just creates budget crises.
insights.practicalTip: Defend reserves with risk data, not gut feel

wp1_correct.text: This is what I needed—an itemized breakdown I can defend to the board. Approved.

wp2_correct.text: I appreciate the range. This tells me you've thought about what could go wrong. Let's budget $425K.

wp3_correct.text: Makes sense. We spent about $90K per location last time. This tracks with what I expected.

hierarchy_correct.text: This is exactly how I need to present it to the board. Cost baseline, reserves, total funding. Approved.

screens.title: Justify the Reserve Amounts to the Board
screens.context: Elena is presenting the $2.8M budget to the board. A board member challenges: 'Why do we need $300K in reserves on top of the $2.5M estimate? Isn't that just padding?'

questions.question: Match each reserve type to its correct characteristics:
How do you characterize the $300K reserves?

options.text: Standard industry practice—all projects include reserves
Justified by risk analysis, not padding
A safety cushion in case we go over budget

questions.question: What's a specific example of a KNOWN risk that contingency covers?

options.text: Future market crashes we can't predict
Supply chain delays—20% probability, $150K impact
General cost overruns that might happen

questions.question: Why does approving only $2.5M create risk?

options.text: Any identified risk instantly triggers a budget overrun
We might need to request more money later anyway
It's below what PMI recommends

screens.title: Key Takeaways
screens.summary: You've learned to select cost estimation techniques based on data availability and detail needs, and to structure budgets with proper reserve allocation.
takeaways: Bottom-Up: High detail, high accuracy, requires WBS (best for clear scope, itemized breakdown needed)
Analogous: Low detail, quick, requires historical data (best for early planning)
Parametric: Medium detail, requires cost-per-unit parameter (best for scalable work)
Three-Point: Addresses uncertainty with range estimates (best for high uncertainty)
Budget Hierarchy: Cost Baseline → + Contingency (known risks) = Project Budget → + Management (unknowns) = Total Funding
Contingency reserves: PM controls, for identified risks in risk register
Management reserves: Sponsor controls, for unforeseeable events
